awd_titl_txt: Berry College MRI:  Aquisition of a Flex Real-Time PCR System for Undergraduate Research and Teaching
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Berry College to increase the research productivity of faculty and enhance undergraduate research and teaching through the acquisition of an Applied Biosystems QuantStudio 7 Flex Real-Time PCR system.  Over the three-year grant period, the QuantStudio 7 will enable faculty to engage an estimated 77 undergraduate research assistants and 312 undergraduates in coursework, teaching them modern molecular techniques and comprehensively preparing them for graduate school and careers in science. This instrument will create opportunities for undertaking new laboratory exercises and engaging in research within the classroom in a diverse set of courses, including Molecular Biology, Developmental Biology, Genetics of Domesticated Animals, and Chromatin, Epigenetics, and Gene Expression. The QuantStudio 7 will also facilitate partnerships between Berry and other institutions, including Dalton State College (an HSI) and Colorado State University.  In partnership with Armuchee High School (serving economically diverse students) and the Georgia Governor's Honors Program (a summer program held on the Berry campus that serves Georgia's top science students from diverse backgrounds), Berry will provide an estimated 348 high school students with early exposure to molecular research instrumentation and methods, which will help build their confidence in their ability to pursue STEM majors and careers. Given the impact of Berry's activities using the QuantStudio 7, as well as the research and training planned by shared users in the Northwest Georgia region, this instrument will play a role in producing the qualified STEM workers the state needs to meet projected STEM employment growth. It will also further Berry's strategic goal to graduate students who are "life ready" prepared to be agents of improvement through the integration of rigorous academic learning with meaningful applied learning experiences and a heart for service. 

The QuantStudio 7 will foster and facilitate the OneHealth approach to research, i.e., transdisciplinary collaborations between physicians, veterinarians, epidemiologists, ecologists, climatologists, medical researchers, and numerous other specialties, as dictated by the specific problem being studied. In the immediate future, the QuantStudio 7 will bring together the project's four PIs a diverse group that includes three early-career investigators and other faculty who collectively are studying coral reef ecosystem health, wildlife and domesticated animal health, and parasites related to human health.  With access to a modern real-time PCR system, the PIs' research will advance understanding of a broad spectrum of molecular mechanisms. Specifically, the PIs will use the instrument to study potential immune genes and endocrine disruption in cnidarians to better understand how these organisms respond to a changing environment; develop an ideal method for cryopreserving eggs, sperm, and embryos of goat and deer species for agricultural purposes and wildlife conservation; and determine how genetic variants affect early pregnancy and thus facilitate genetic selection programs to improve cow fertility. The PIs will disseminate their research findings through submission of papers to peer-reviewed journals and presentations at national and international meetings.  Overall, the QuantStudio 7's robust capabilities will advance future investigations in interconnections between human, animal, and environmental health.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Acquisition of the QuantStudio7 Real Time PCR machine has brought together the four PIs on this project, which represent a diverse group that includes two early-career investigators and other faculty who collectively are studying animal and environmental health. Having access to a modern real-time PCR system has advanced the PIs' research regarding a broad spectrum of molecular mechanisms. To date, the QuantStudio7 has promoted the completion of several projects.  PI Poole has completed her proposed project on measuring gene expression of GTPases of Immunity Associated Proteins (GIMAPs) in the anemone E. pallida in response to immune stimulation and induction of apoptosis and autophagy, two cell death related processes.  These results were published in 2020 with two undergraduate co-authors. Additionally, it has led to the design of several new projects to investigate the molecular mechanisms underlying cnidarian symbiosis. Co-PI Morgan has used the QuantStudio7 in several projects including the research proposed in the MRI grant involving identification of molecular biomarkers that can differentiate exposure of cnidarians to exogenous chemicals of environmental relevance. Additionally, he has investigated the response of the coral Montipora grisea to fungal infection and a root fungal infection in American and Chinese Chestnuts. Co-PI Peters completed a project on the effects of dietary supplementation of newly weaned beef steers on performance, immunity, plasma metabolome, and fecal bacterial community that resulted in two publications. Lastly, Co-PI Bresnahan is currently working on a project to develop improved in vitro embryo production and cryopreservation of gametes and embryos from goats and white-tailed deer as a model for domesticated species. Thus, the QuantStudio7 has elevated the research capabilities of faculty at Berry College, and they are contributing to important fields including coral reef ecosystem health, environmental toxicology, and wild and domesticated animal health.

Broader Impacts: This award was made to Berry College to increase the research productivity of faculty and enhance undergraduate research and teaching. Over duration of the grant period, 23 undergraduate research assistants have been trained on the machine. Additionally, the QuantStudio7 has been used for educational purposes in the Developmental Biology course at Berry College. During the summer of 2019, PI Poole began work with the Georgia Governor's Honors Program (a summer program held at Berry College that serves Georgia's top science students from diverse backgrounds). Specifically, she collaborated with high school teacher Laura Williford, the instructor for the agricultural science course, and together they designed a project on molecular detection of beneficial plant symbionts on Berry College campus. For this project, students collected soil samples, extracted microbial DNA, and performed PCR on the samples using published primers. The goal of future summers is to progress to running these samples on the QuantStudio7. Additionally, PI Poole educated GHP students about the difference between traditional PCR and qPCR techniques. Overall, the QuantStudio7 has provided opportunities for training faculty, undergraduate researchers, high school teachers, and high school students in new techniques. Therefore, this grant has supported several of the desired societal outcomes of NSF including enhanced infrastructure for research and education and improved STEM education.
